title: Haley Joel Osment charged with cocaine possession and being drunk in public
text:
Oscar-nominated actor Haley Joel Osment has been charged with public intoxication and cocaine possession after his arrest earlier this month at a Northern California ski resort.

The Mono County District Attorney's office announced the misdemeanor charges Thursday against the 37-year-old actor, who starred as a child in movies "The Sixth Sense" and "A.I."

Osment was arrested April 8 at the Mammoth Mountain ski resort on suspicion of public intoxication, District Attorney David Anderson said in a news release.

READ MORE: Woman kidnapped from home before body found in burnt out car ﻿

Haley Joel Osment attends a screening of "Poker Face" during PaleyFest on Saturday, March 29, 2025, at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles. (Photo by Willy Sanjuan/Invision/AP, File) (Willy Sanjuan/Invision/AP)

The actor is due to be arraigned on July 7.

His representative did not immediately return a message seeking comment on the charges Thursday.

Osment rose to fame and received a best supporting actor Oscar nomination for starring opposite Bruce Willis in M. Night Shyamalan's thriller "The Sixth Sense."

Two years later he starred in Steven Spielberg's "A.I." and has worked consistently as a voice actor since then.

He's also appeared in the television series "The Kominsky Method" and "What We Do in the Shadows."

Osment is among the thousands of people who lost their homes in January's devastating Eaton Fire in the Altadena area near Los Angeles.

title: Restaurant chain faces outrage after carving up 500-year-old oak tree
text:
A restaurant chain has apologised after sparking outrage when it cut down an oak tree in London that was believed to be up to 500 years old.

Described by British conservation charity the Woodland Trust as "one of London's largest and most significant ancient trees," the huge oak was located outside a branch of Toby Carvery, a popular restaurant chain known for its roast dinners, in Whitewebbs Park in the borough of Enfield.

The tree's remains, surrounded by its severed branches, were discovered by council workers on April 3. Enfield Council owns the land the tree was located on, and it is leased to Toby Carvery.

A centuries-old oak tree in Enfield, London, was cut down earlier this month. (James Veysey/Shutterstock via CNN Newsource)

The owner of Toby Carvery, Mitchells & Butlers, said the chain was advised by contractors to cut the tree as it "caused a potential health and safety risk."

With a girth of 6.1 metres, the tree ranked in the top 100 of London's 600,000 oak trees for size, according to the Woodland Trust.

"I am outraged that the leaseholder has cut down this beautiful ancient oak tree without seeking any permissions or advice from Enfield Council," said Ergin Erbil, the leader of Enfield Council, in a statement Wednesday. "We have evidence that this tree was alive and starting to grow new spring leaves when this action was taken."

He said the council believes the action has "broken the terms of the lease which requires Toby Carvery to maintain and protect the existing landscape."

"The tree was the oldest one on site and cutting it down seems to be a clear breach of this condition. This tree would have been home to countless wildlife, fungi, and pollinators. This tree is a part of our ecological and cultural heritage," he added.

The council said it is considering legal action.

According to the council, when experts inspected the oak in December, it was deemed "healthy" and "posed no risk" to the neighbouring carpark and its users. An emergency tree preservation order has been imposed on the base of the stump, the Woodland Trust said.

A spokesperson for Mitchells & Butlers said in a statement to CNN that the felling of the tree was "an important action to protect our employees and guests as well as the wider general public."

"We took necessary measures to ensure any legal requirements were met," it added.

Phil Urban, the chain's CEO, later apologized for "all the anger and upset that this incident has caused."

"Clearly the felling of a beautiful old tree is a very emotive subject and is not something that any of us would undertake lightly," said Urban in a letter addressing the incident. "We cannot undo what has been done," he said, adding: "We need to tighten our protocols."

Benny Hawksbee, who lives in Enfield and is a member of the Guardians of Whitewebbs group, said in the Woodland Trust statement that people want "answers."

"The tree belonged to Enfield and to our national heritage. I am devastated," said Hawksbee.

Jon Stokes, director of trees, science and research at the Tree Council, said in the trust's statement that ancient oaks can live up to 1,000 years.

Despite the damage, council leader Erbil said the oak "shows clear signs of life," adding: "We will also do everything we can to help the tree regrow."

The Metropolitan Police Service told CNN in a statement Thursday that it was treating the felling as a civil matter and has closed its investigation.

This is not the first time that the felling of a tree has sparked outrage in the United Kingdom.

title: Election war of words erupts over $180b tax break for investors
text:
A﻿n election war of words has broken out over negative gearing and the capital gains tax discount as new data reveals the multibillion-dollar cost of the tax breaks.

Voters are split over the controversial concessions and both major parties have been grilled over their plans this federal election.

While the Greens have lobbied hard for a reform﻿ and leader Adam Bandt blamed the capital gains discount for the housing crisis, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Opposition Leader Peter Dutton have denied there will be any changes made to either.

Peter Dutton said during the second debate that cutting negative gearing would hurt renters. (James Brickwood)

Reports first emerged last year that federal Treasury had investigated a potential overhaul of the tax concessions awarded to property owners.

"It certainly wasn't commissioned by us to do so," the PM said when asked during the second debate on Wednesday night about the Treasury modelling.

But Treasurer Jim Chalmers had publicly stated back in September that he asked Treasury for "advice" about the subject, leading Dutton to claim in the debate that Albanese had a "problem with the truth".

Chalmers yesterday sought to strike a clear difference between that advice and "modelling".

"I've said on a number of occasions now that I sought a view," Chalmers said.

"Now that's different to commissioning modelling. The prime minister was asked about commissioning modelling. I sought a view."

Chalmers said it was "normal practice" to seek advice on such a matter and that the Treasury's view was a change to negative gearing "wouldn't get the sort of improvement that we desperately need to see in our economy when it comes to supply".

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was accused of lying over the Treasury's move to seek advice on negative gearing. (Alex Ellinghausen)

He said Labor was "not proposing any changes in this area".

﻿Shadow treasurer Angus Taylor claimed Albanese "lied" about plans to raise housing taxes during the debate.

"The prime minister last night denied his government had modelled negative gearing changes. The treasurer confirmed in September it had," Taylor said.

"The prime minister lied to the Australian public on camera about his hidden plans to raise taxes on housing."

Dutton argued cutting negative gearing would worsen the rental market.

"I have stated very clearly, we want a sustainable housing market, which includes rental stock," the opposition leader when debate moderator David Speers asked why his party wouldn't change the capital gains tax discount or negative gearing.

"If you want to cut out negative gearing, as the Labor Party and the Greens would love to do, you will stop investment taking place for properties that are ultimately rented by young Australians."

Greens leader Adam Bandt said the Greens would reform tax concessions for investors. (Alex Ellinghausen)

READ MORE: When shops will be open and closed this Easter around the country

A report released today by parliament revealed the cost of revenue forgone due to both negative gearing deductions and capital gains discounts was $11.9 ﻿billion in the 2024/25 financial year.

It's estimated the combined cost will reach $180.5 billion over the next 10 years from 2026/27 until 2035/36.

Greens spokesperson for housing and homelessness Max Chandler-Mather said the Greens would work to abolish "massive tax handouts" for property investors.

"The Greens will right the wrongs of decades of housing failure and end the tax handouts for investors with more than one investment property that are turbocharging house prices and denying renters the chance to buy a home," Chandler-Mather said.

"How is it fair that a young family loses at an auction to an investor buying their 10th property because that investor has massive tax handouts from the government?"

Former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull said in a post on X that negative gearing is "examined by every government".

﻿"It is a major tax concession and always contentious and so it is always looked at – what does it cost?" Turnbull said.

"What would particular changes mean in terms of revenue and housing affordability."

title: Where you can and can't buy alcohol today and over Easter
text:
Many Australians love a drink or two over the Easter holidays , but the country's liquor trading laws restrict what can and can't be sold over the long weekend.

Good Friday and the Easter weekend are some of the only days of the year that have specific restrictions on alcohol sales.

If you're in the mood for a tipple, here are the best options and what you need to know.﻿

Most states will see restrictions on trading hours for alcohol purchases across venues and retail outlets. (AAP)

New South Wales

On Good Friday there is a blanket ban on all takeaway sales, whether you want a bottle from a shop, pub or restaurant - which means most liquor retail outlets will be closed in New South Wales.

Most licensed premises will offer﻿ drinks in-house on Good Friday, though for some you may need to sit down with a meal.

Saturday ﻿will see regular trading hours for licensed premises and retail outlets.

On Easter Sunday normal trading hours resume for licensed premises but most retail outlets will be restricted again and closed.

Victoria﻿

Similar to New South Wales, Good Friday closes bottle shops unless specifically permitted otherwise.

On-premise purchases are allowed﻿ and will be offered at venues, restaurants and cafes.

Venues are generally allowed to top up your glass from noon, but if your local go-to is a brewery or a distiller, you can head over at 10am.

It's safe to say regular trading hours resume Easter Saturday and Sunday - ﻿ Victoria's liquor laws don't mention any particular restrictions.

READ MORE:﻿ When shops will be open and closed this Easter around the country

Some states will require you to have a 'sit-down' meal in order to purchase a drink on the venue. (A Current Affair)

Queensland

Similar to Victoria, ﻿Good Friday affects trading hours of licensed premises in Queensland.

Takeaway alcohol can't be sold, so retail outlets will be closed.

However, you can buy drinks at venues from 10am to midnight, but only with a sit-down meal - as per the state government's website .

They even go as far to specifically tell us what a meal is.﻿

"A meal is food that can be eaten with cutlery while seated— for example, roast beef with vegetables"

"It is not light takeaway food like snacks, hot chips, an entrée or kid's meal."

Regular trading hours resume Easter Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

READ MORE: Almost every state and territory is expecting rain over Easter long weekend

South Australia

After legal reforms several years ago, South Australia has had all alcohol sale restrictions lifted.

Currently, South Australia has no restrictions on the sale of alcohol on Good Friday, and for the rest of the weekend.

This means venues can choose to be open over the weekend for purchases and takeaways.

Western Australia﻿

In the west of the nation, ﻿liquor stores will be closed on Good Friday.

However, people will be allowed to have a Good Friday drink﻿ with a meal in most clubs, hotels, pubs, and restaurants.

Clubs will remain open until 3am.﻿

Regular trading hours resume for the rest of the weekend.﻿

Saturday will see regular trading hours across the country. (Nine)

Northern Territory﻿

Takeaway sales are restricted on Good Friday.

You can still buy drinks at venues like restaurants, bars and clubs between 11am to 9pm so long as you buy a full, sit-down meal as well.﻿

No finger foods, sandwiches and pies for those bargaining for a drink too - the territory's website says.

Australian Capital Territory

﻿For the territory where you can find the federal government, you would expect there to be harsher restrictions over the quiet, long weekend.

But patrons can keep partying over the weekend as there are no restrictions on alcohol sales or trading hours﻿ on Good Friday.

Tasmania﻿

The Apple Isle ﻿will see an equally, loosely restricted Easter weekend.

Tasmania remains much the same with no restrictions on sales or trading hours over the long weekend.﻿

title: 'Thoughtless' ghost campers costing small businesses big money
text:
A "thoughtless" camping trend in Victoria is costing local communities big money.

The frustrating practice of "ghost camping" – which is when holidaymakers book multiple free camping spots but fail to turn up – is hurting small businesses this Easter.

Some blame Victoria Premier Jacinta Allan for opening the floodgates after she announced campers can stay in every national park and state forest across the state from December 1 last year.

A fully booked camping ground in Tidal River. (Facebook)

The move wiped out $7.3 million in annual booking fees for campers but it's come at another high cost.

It might be the middle of the school holidays, but some usually bustling camping grounds are sitting half-empty.

"People are booking them in advance and just not turning up," one camper at Tidal River campground, a popular site in Wilsons Prom in southern Victoria, told 9News.

Brett Beaumont, who operates the Open Air Cinema near the campground, said his business was down 65 per cent on last year.

"There's 484 campsites, roughly 150 would be occupied at the moment," Beaumont said.

"The consequences are my business, which has struggled."

Beaumont claims that, in extreme cases, some families booked out a spot for an entire month when they couldn't decide which weekend to stay.

Where is the Aussie dollar still good value for travellers? View Gallery

Nationals MP Melina Bath said she wasn't pleased to see ghost camping at the popular Tidal River spot.

"Despite the website showing Tidal River as being fully booked, there are plenty of spare campsites and it appears quite a few 'no shows' or multiple party bookings for space," Bath said.

"Ghost camping looks set to continue harming local businesses and abandoning needed revenue."

The move wiped out $7.3 million in annual booking fees but it's come at another high cost. (Facebook)

Back in January, fellow Nationals MP Danny O'Brien also took aim at the state government's free camping initiative.

"It's a shame people are so thoughtless but this could've been avoided with some foresight - require a refundable deposit or re-let sites if someone doesn't show up within 24 hours etc," he said on Facebook.

"Several campers stopped me as I had a look tonight to complain at what a waste it is, with international visitors and many others turned away when there are sites sitting unused.

"This has been repeated around the state and will certainly have robbed many communities of vital summer income as visitor numbers are artificially depressed."

Victoria Minister for Environment Steve Dimopoulos said in a statement that Victorians weren't trying to "abuse" the system.

"I don't buy that, Victorians want to do the right thing, that's why Parks Victoria now send out two reminders to people to cancel if they can't make their booking, so that other people don't miss out," Dimopoulos said.

"We introduced free camping to get more Victorian families out having holidays in the regions and putting money back in their pockets."

"We want more Victorians to explore the great outdoors this Easter weekend, in addition to the 131 bookable campgrounds, Victorians can also stay at one of the 1000 free camping areas that are first-come-first-served across the state."

title: When shops will be open and closed today and over Easter weekend
text:
D﻿ashing to the shops for a quick pick-up will become more complicated than usual this Easter long weekend , with supermarkets and big stores shutting down today around the country.

It's best to shop early and be prepared, but that can be difficult with different shops shutting at different times depending on where you are in the country.

Here's what you need to know about when and where you can shop.﻿

Major shops will operate on different schedules over the Easter long weekend. (Alex Ellinghausen)

What's open on Good Friday?

Woolworths confirmed it would close stores around the country today with some exceptions.

Those exceptions include the stores at Brisbane Airport in Queensland; Mount Barker, Mount Barker South, and Murray Bridge Marketplace Victor Harbo﻿r in South Australia; Dunsborough, Perth Airport, Eaton Fair, Margaret River, Busselton, and Dalyellup in Western Australia.

Coles will close all its stores except for those at Victor Harbor, Murray Bridge Green, and Mount Barker in South Australia.

Bunnings and Aldi stores will be shut for the day nationwide.﻿

People are urged to get their shopping done early. (Getty)

What's open on Easter Saturday?﻿

All Woolworths stores will reopen tomorrow for Easter Saturday, except for several Metro outlets around the country.﻿

Coles will likewise be open nationwide, though some stores will be operating with reduced trading hours.

Aldi and Bunnings stores will be open as well.

What's open on Easter Sunday?

﻿Aldi stores will all open in Victoria and Western Australia, but it will vary around the rest of the country. Some shops will open, some won't.

Bunnings will also be open on Easter Sunday, though trading hours will be reduced in New South Wales.﻿

Woolworths' status will vary state to state. All stores will be open in Queensland, Victoria, Tasmania, and Western Australia, with a couple of exceptions (Esperance in Western Australia, Moama in Victoria, Hervey Bay Pialba and some Metro stores in Queensland).

READ MORE: The election promises Labor and the Coalition have made to win your vote

Shops will be closed for multiple days. (Getty)

In NSW, the ACT, South Australia, and the Northern Territory, "a handful" of Woolies stores will open, with people encouraged to check the opening hours of their local outlet online .﻿

﻿Similarly, Coles stores will operate differently around the country.

Shops will be closed in NSW, and open in Tasmania and the ACT.

Outlets in Victoria, Queensland, and Western Australia will be open, but some will operate within reduced trading hours.

All shops will be open for reduced ours in the NT.

In South Australia, all stores will be closed except for Port Lincoln, Port Pirie, Port Augusta, Adelaide Rundle Place, Whyalla, Murray Bridge Green, Mount Gambier, Victor Harbor, and Mount Barker.﻿

Honking goose at the centre of high-profile divorce case View Gallery

What's open on Easter Monday?

Woolworths will open their doors again for NSW, the ACT, Victoria, Western Australia, and Tasmania.﻿

Stores will reopen in Queensland except for Hervey Bay, Pialba.

A handful of stores will be open in South Australia and the NT.﻿

Coles will reopen stores in every state and territory except South Australia, though in most areas (NSW, Queensland, Victoria, Western Australia, and the NT) trading hours will be reduced.

Tasmania and the ACT will trade unrestricted.

South Australian stores will be closed except for Port Lincoln, Port Pirie, Port Augusta, Adelaide Rundle Place, Whyalla, Murray Bridge Green, Mount Gambier, Victor Harbor, Mount Barker, and Berri.﻿

Aldi outlets will be open in most states and territories, but it will vary store to store in South Australia.﻿

Bunnings stores will be open around the country.

The provided trading hours and information are subject to change according to individual stores. We highly encourage readers to check the operating hours of their local stores online before making the venture. ﻿

title: Final date added to Lady Gaga's Australian tour
text:
An extra date has been added to Lady Gaga's Australian tour as the singer prepares to perform her first-ever stadium shows on our shores.

Gaga will bring her Mayhem Ball to Melbourne's Marvel Stadium, Brisbane's Suncorp Stadium and Sydney's Accor Stadium in December.

An additional Sydney show was announced today as tickets went on sale to the public.

Lady﻿ Gaga will perform her first-ever Australian stadium shows in December. (Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Coachella)

The singer is set to perform at Coachella this weekend before she embarks on a world tour to promote her new album Mayhem .

She will travel through Mexico City, Singapore, the US, Canada, the UK and Europe before the show reaches Australia.

Where is Lady Gaga playing in Australia?

Lady﻿ Gaga will perform shows in Melbourne, Brisbane and Sydney this December.

The singer will kick off the Australian leg of Mayhem Ball in Melbourne at Marvel Stadium in Melbourne on December 5 and 6.

This will be followed ﻿by a show at Suncorp Stadium in Brisbane on December 9 and a show at Accor Stadium in Sydney on December 12.﻿

READ MORE: When shops will be open and closed this Easter around the country

The pop star will embark on a world tour following her performance at Coachella. (Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Coachella)

A fifth and final show was later announced for Accor Stadium on December 13.

"Due to overwhelming demand, a second stadium date for Sydney has been added to the Australian leg of Lady Gaga's global tour," promoter Live Nation said.

"This will be the final date added to this local run of shows."

When was the last time Lady Gaga toured Australia?

Lady Gaga will touch down on our shores for the first time in 11 years.

Gaga last toured Australia in 2014 ﻿for the ArtRave: The Artpop Ball tour.

The singer performed six concerts in four Australian cities including Perth, Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney.

When do Lady Gaga tickets go on sale?

Tickets for the second Sydney new show will be available from Tuesday, April 22.

A pre-sale event, run by Vodafone and Mastercard, will open from 11.30am (AEST).

A second pre-sale event, run by touring company Live Nation, ﻿will start from 11.30am (AEST) on Wednesday, April 23.

General sale tickets will be made available from 12.30pm (AEST) on Thursday, April 24.﻿

Tickets to the singer's other dates opened to the public on Thursday, April 17.

Wild fashion and on-stage antics during weekend one of Coachella View Gallery

How much do Lady Gaga tickets cost?

Fans who were able to secure tickets in the pre-sale have speculated about the use of dynamic pricing, a system where the price of tickets changes based on demand.

However a Ticketmaster spokesperson denied the use of surge pricing.﻿

"Ticketmaster does not have surge pricing or dynamic algorithms to adjust ticket prices," a spokesperson said.

"Tickets were priced in advance of the sale and set at the individual seat level."

According to the Ticketmaster , tickets (including VIP packages) have been priced in advance from $118.68 to $1586.76 for the Brisbane and Sydney shows with a handling fee of $7.95 per order.

Tickets for the Melbourne shows are priced between $113.06 and $1581.12 and a handling fee of $9.90 per order will apply.

title: Chaos erupts in cinema leaving moviegoers 'choking and crying'
text:
Moviegoers were left "choking and crying" after unruly teenagers set off a fire extinguisher inside a cinema in Melbourne's east.

A bizarre trend taking place during screenings of A Minecraft Movie, where cinemas erupt into chaos upon one particular scene, was taken to a new level at Eastland Hoyts in Ringwood.

Melbourne mother Mel told 3AW her kids were left "terrified" after teenagers pulled the pin on a fire extinguisher inside a dark cinema.

Melbourne mother Mel told 3AW her kids were left "terrified". (TikTok/ finlayw14_)

"It scared a lot of children, a lot of grandparents," Mel told hosts Mark Allen and Jimmy Bartel.

"You couldn't breathe, you couldn't swallow, the kids were choking, my kids were crying, their eyes were burning."

Footage of the fire extinguisher incident was also shared on TikTok.

Mel said Hoyts checked the bags of some moviegoers and confiscated items such as flour and toilet paper.

She claimed several teenagers later snuck out to grab the fire extinguisher mid-film.

"I don't know where they got it from," Mel said.

"And then, bang. We were completely doused in it."

Hoyts staff moved the innocent attendees to another room where they continued playing the film.

Footage of the fire extinguisher incident was also shared on TikTok. (TikTok/ finlayw14_)

Usually, fans respond to a scene titled 'Chicken Jockey' by throwing popcorn, clapping and screaming.

This has become a viral trend on social media, filled with videos of overblown reactions to the popular Jack Black film.

Another mother of a Hoyts employee told 3AW her son had been a regular witness to this disruptive behaviour.

"Everyday he comes home with a new story about what kids have smuggled in their bags to try and throw at the screen," Helen* said.

"Yesterday there was roast chicken, some flour.. They've got longer shifts and more cleaning to do."

READ MORE: The election promises Labor and the Coalition have made to win your vote

Helen said workers have been asked to check bags before people enter the cinema for A Minecraft Movie.

"They're not security guards, they're 15 and 16-year-olds, and this is their part-time job," she added.

9news.com.au has contacted Hoyts for comment.

*Not her real name.﻿

title: 'A stain on society': Brisbane's Lachie Neale condemns online trolls
text:
Brisbane premiership captain Lachie Neale has spoken out on the online abuse AFL players face, calling those responsible "a stain on society."

Speaking in the aftermath of the Lions' heavy loss to Collingwood overnight, Neale took to Instagram to hammer the social media trolling he believes has gotten out of hand.

“People hiding behind keyboards to attack players are the biggest stain on society,” Neale posted.

“It’s getting beyond a joke now, the things I’ve seen sent are some of the most horrific messages I’ve ever seen. It’s a game of football, grow the f**k up.

"Cowards. Put your face and name to your words.”

Neale's specific concerns remain unknown as of Friday morning but the Lions have confirmed the matter had been reported to the AFL.

The 31-year old was speaking in the aftermath of the Lions' 52-point loss to Collingwood on Thursday night which doubled as their first defeat of the season.

More to come.

title: Could New Zealand be headed for its own Robodebt episode?
text:
The Robodebt scheme is remembered as one of the biggest public policy scandals in modern Australia but there are fears history could repeat itself across the Tasman.

New Zealand's conservative government is currently trying to expand the use of "automated decision-making" in the welfare system as part of a concerted effort to rein in public spending.

But critics fear the reforms will take crucial decisions about vulnerable people out of the hands of humans and allow algorithms to determine who receives benefits.

Salvation Army social policy advocate Ana Ika understands the government wants to be more efficient "but efficiency comes at a cost".

"This cost has human lives and those are human lives the Salvation Army sees every day," she said.

New Zealand's Ministry of Social Development has moved to allay concerns, arguing the technology will make the welfare system easier for people.

"Any decision to decline a benefit will always be made by a staff member," deputy chief executive of organisational assurance and communications Melissa Gill said.

"There are also no plans to change this."

What is 'automated decision-making'?

The huge public interest in artificial intelligence has prompted questions about how automation is being used by governments and businesses. (Supplied: Jon McCormack)

Automated decision-making (ADM) describes a broad range of computerised systems that use rules-based processes to assist or replace human choices.

They range from online forms that determine how much you can borrow from a bank, to real-time, data-driven algorithms that dictate prices on ride share apps.

The ministry used the technology in 2022 to automatically grant a winter energy subsidy to more than 858,000 people, a process they say would have required about 600 full-time staff members, working for eight weeks straight.

"This would create extra cost to taxpayers and potentially delays to clients," Ms Gill said.

It now wants to use ADM to check whether welfare recipients have met the requirements to renew their benefits, with those rejected having to speak with a staff member.

"The wellbeing and dignity of our clients is paramount, and any ADM use must balance efficiency with these values," Ms Gill said.

But some advocates question whether there are enough safeguards in place to ensure the technology won't inadvertently cause a scandal similar to Robodebt.

Bad technology, bad decisions

Welfare recipients are often also supported by emergency food services, such as The Waka of Caring in South Auckland. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Robodebt was a debt-recovery scheme introduced by Australia's former conservative government in 2016 that promised to use automation to save billions of dollars.

But serious design flaws created more than 400,000 false debt notices and a royal commission was established amid allegations of political malfeasance and suggestions the fake debts contributed to several suicides.

New Zealand's government isn't trying to establish a debt-recovery scheme similar to Robodebt but the broad provisions governing the use of automation contained in the Social Security Amendment Bill have legal experts concerned.

The New Zealand Law Society said the clause regarding automated decision-making "is not limited in any way and the accompanying documentation for the bill contains no analysis of the proposal".

"It is unclear how automated systems are intended to accurately and appropriately operate where evaluative judgement is required," it said in a submission to a parliamentary committee considering the legislation.

Learning from Australia's mistakes

Charities fear the expansion of automated decision-making will negatively impact some of New Zealand's most vulnerable. (Reuters: Tomas Cuesta)

In the months before Australia's Robodebt Royal Commission in 2022, New Zealand's Ministry of Social Development introduced a set of standards to govern the use of ADM, including provisions to ensure transparency and ways to appeal automated decisions.

The standards are being reviewed this year in consultation with New Zealand's privacy commissioner.

Ms Gill said the ministry was "able to learn from what happened in Australia and other parts of the world" and ensure its safeguards would "help to prevent many of the same problems we have seen with the use of AI in other social welfare systems".

"MSD's ADM Standard includes additional requirements for the use of complex algorithms," she said.

"These requirements place greater oversight over the algorithm's development and ensure that privacy, human rights, and ethics considerations are addressed before the algorithm can be used."

But the Salvation Army remains wary of the further expansion of automation, as Ms Ika said there were already incidents where miscalculations impacted clients.

"Introducing additional layers on top of the complexities that are already there in the welfare system will just push people more into hardship," she said.

Ms Ika fears automation will lead to a "blanket approach" for some of New Zealand's most vulnerable people.

"It actually takes human oversight to be able to understand the context and the complexities of where families are coming from," she said.

Navigating the ethics of automation

Many of the clients supported by the Salvation Army have complex backgrounds and circumstances. (ABC Central West: Melanie Pearce)

The wave of public interest in artificial intelligence has prompted fresh questions about how governments and businesses use automated processes, from complex generative AI models to basic algorithms.

Professor Nicholas Agar examines the ethical implications of new technology at the University of Waikato and said AI had tremendous potential to solve complex problems and help vulnerable people.

But "the amazing upside" needed to be balanced with the potential risks.

"Often, when you're using a technology that you don't fully understand, and even those who make it [AI] don't fully understand it, stuff can go wrong and that hurts people," he said.

" People who go into AI cluelessly are going to have a bad ending. It's sort of a Robodebt kind of ending. "

The reforms to the welfare system come as the New Zealand government tries to get 50,000 people off Jobseeker payments and into work by 2030.

Professor Agar said AI technology could be harnessed to help connect vulnerable people with services "if we really asked it to do the right things".

"AI can be great but if you're vague about your goals, and you say, let's make this cheaper, well, then it can be very bad," he said.

Will the laws actually improve outcomes?

Economist Michael Fletcher has concerns about the proposed legislation beyond the expanded use of automation. (Supplied)

Like many public discussions about future technology, the reality will often be very different from the risks and rewards debated today.

Economist Michael Fletcher, who was a member of the New Zealand government's Welfare Expert Advisory Group, was surprised the Robodebt scandal was not explicitly mentioned in the government's "regulatory impact statement".

But he has broader concerns about the punitive measures included in the legislation, from forcing jobseekers to reapply for benefits every six months instead of annually, to the use of cashless welfare cards.

"The rhetoric is around, 'Getting into work is the best way to improve outcomes and so'. My problem with this bill is that it doesn't actually do any of that," he said.

"It is all about a suite of measures to make it harder to get on to the benefit and harder to stay on the benefit rather than any assistance for people to go into work.

"It should really be called the social security 'hoops and hurdles' bill because that is really what it's all about."

As part of the welfare reforms, the government has introduced a new "traffic light system" to indicate whether a client is meeting their obligations to receive a benefit.

Non-financial "sanctions" can be issued for those who fail to meet them, such as requirements to attend training programs or complete "job-search activities".

Social Development and Employment Minister Louise Upton in February said these sanctions "will ensure there is accountability in the welfare system for those who aren't taking reasonable steps to seek employment".

"It's important that beneficiaries who can work are taking reasonable steps to re-enter the workforce or remain work-ready, and that consequences exist for those who don't," she said.

title: Nervous wait for surfers as station around famous break for sale
text:
A much-loved pastoral station and surfing hotspot skirting Western Australia's remote Ningaloo coast has been listed for public sale for the first time since 2005.

Spanning more than 84,000 hectares of land near Carnarvon, almost 900 kilometres north of Perth, the origins of Gnaraloo Station can be traced to the early 1900s.

Today, it is most famous for its high winds and ready access to world-class surf.

Gnaraloo Station borders the southern entrance of the Ningaloo World Heritage Site. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Perth realtor Jarrad O'Rourke is overseeing the sale, with both the pastoral and tourism leases carrying a combined asking price of around $17 million.

"People are very protective of it," he said.

"[The lease holder] doesn't want to sell it to the highest bidder … it is still currently affordable for most, and it's the most amazing place on Earth."

The property's heavy barrelling, left-handed break has earned the moniker Tombstones from locals, captivating and testing some of the country's most seasoned board-riders.

This surf mecca helped sustain the former sheep station amid a decades-long dispute with WA government authorities over the viability of maintaining stock.

Twist in land stoush

In 2006, current lease holder Paul Richardson surrendered a 2-kilometre stretch of coastline to the Commonwealth following lengthy negotiations around the Ningaloo Marine Park.

The pastoralist later alleged the annexed strip was mismanaged by the WA Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA), leading to erosion and the predation of loggerhead sea turtle rookeries.

The station's Three Mile campground is a popular tourist spot and a short walk from the Tombstones surf break. (ABC News)

He also said authorities refused him access to water tanks and troughs, undercutting the possibility of a profitable sheep operation.

Goats nevertheless flourished on the property, with 1,500 included in the station's sale as livestock.

Paul Richardson and DBCA previously fought over goats on the property. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

But these too flared tensions between Mr Richardson and wildlife officials as distinctions between authorised and feral animals blurred.

Mr Richardson declined to comment on the sale.

Surfers cross fingers

Carnarvon local Scotty Bauer has spent years surfing and taking photos off Gnaraloo Station.

"It's essentially in my blood, being raised in the north-west," he said.

Mr Bauer welcomed a possible change in ownership, noting surfers were too often caught in the middle of Mr Richardson's stoush with the state government.

"I hope it's a fresh start for that coastline; it would be great to get someone in there that has some knowledge about running a camp of that nature mindfully," he said.

The surf photographer called for the station's goats to be removed, saying they had driven the World-Heritage listed coastline "into the ground".

"The coast is dying, it's [already] dead is some places — that is a real concern," he said.

The remote station is surrounded by harsh desert. (ABC News)

While tourism became the primary business at Gnaraloo Station when Mr Richardson assumed the lease in 2005, the property has not escaped industrial interest.

Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Metals Group acquired a bevy of exploration leases around the region in 2021, reaching 260km to the south of the station and about 400km to the north.

Analysts speculated the move could form a base for the mining magnate's green hydrogen ambitions, but it is understood the company has scaled back the plans.

Surfer Scotty Bauer welcomed a "fresh start" for the station but warned buyers it "demands respect". (ABC News)

Mr Bauer said the prospect of a developer in tourism, energy or another area snapping up Gnaraloo Station was "always in the back of everyone's minds".

"As a community, we raise [concerns] as they come ... they've got to address all the issues with stakeholders, so good luck to them," he said.

He warned the place, like its famous swell, was not for the faint-hearted.

"It demands respect, really," he said.

title: Spurs surge to Europa League semifinal with defiant victory
text:
A first-half penalty by Dominic Solanke secured Tottenham Hotspur a 1-0 win at Eintracht Frankfurt in the second leg of their Europa League quarter-final on Thursday for a 2-1 aggregate victory.

They will face Lazio in May for a spot in the final.

Solanke gave Tottenham the lead from the spot two minutes before halftime after the visitors were awarded a penalty for a foul by goalkeeper Kaua Santos on Spurs midfielder James Maddison.

Maddison headed the ball before clashing with the arriving Santos, and the referee pointed to the spot following a VAR review.

The win is an important one for manager Ange Postecoglou, who is fighting to hold his job after a difficult domestic season.

"To a man, I thought they were outstanding. I'm so proud of them," said Postecoglou.

"Unfortunately for a lot of you, you're going to have to put up with me a little bit longer, mate.

"We'll just see how that goes."

Tottenham continue their quest to win a first European trophy in more than 40 years after their 1984 UEFA Cup success, something that would give them redemption for a disappointing domestic season.

They reached the last four of a European competition for the first time since their run to the 2019 Champions League final, where they lost 2-0 against fellow Premier League side Liverpool.

Playing in a heavy rain, Eintracht showed more intent in the opening stages but lost Mario Goetze early on after the veteran playmaker suffered what looked like a hamstring injury.

He was replaced by Fares Chaibi, who wasted no time and had a chance with a header soon after but was denied by Tottenham keeper Guglielmo Vicario.

Tottenham were without their captain Son Heung-min, who did not travel due to a foot injury.

Mathys Tel, who signed for Spurs on loan from Bayern Munich in January, started in his place.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

The 19-year-old had the visitors' first attempt on target after 26 minutes, sending a lofted shot from outside the box that forced Eintracht goalkeeper Kaua Santos into a save.

Eintracht, who took a sixth-minute lead in London through a fine Hugo Ekitike strike, were the better side but fell behind when Solanke sent Santos the wrong way converting coolly with a low shot down the middle of the goal.

The German side, champions in 2022, were far from willing to accept their fate and pushed for an equaliser after the restart but were missing a finishing touch.

The hosts stormed Vicario's goal with 15 minutes to go when the goalkeeper denied Chaibi from close range just before Rasmus Kristensen flashed a header just wide.

The Denmark defender had two more chances within the next minutes, shooting wide and being denied by Vicario.

Tottenham won the competition twice, including its inaugural edition in 1972 when they beat Wolverhampton Wanderers 3-2 on aggregate in a two-legged final.

Reuters

title: Blast from the past as Callide power plant presents first scandal for LNP
text:
Rocked by a coal-fired controversy, the LNP has been sent into damage control for the first time since its Queensland election win.

What should have been a simple exercise in lashing its Labor predecessors has put a pep in the opposition's step and sent the government's agenda offline.

The fallout from an explosion at the troubled Central Queensland Callide power station on April 4 has led the chief executive of the government-owned operator, CS Energy, to have his resignation brought forward, and another senior employee to leave the company.

It followed a less-than-stellar press conference in which Energy Minister David Janetzki conceded he should have mentioned the blast in a major energy address days after it happened.

One of Central Queensland power plant's generators will be offline until end of May. (ABC News: Scout Wallen)

The CS Energy board took the hit for the under-fire minister on Wednesday, admitting in a statement the company "understated the gravity" of the incident and there had not been "adequate reporting of serious issues".

But for a government which prides itself on media management and communication, the saga has seen its wires crossed.

It's struggled to wrestle control of the narrative, as Mr Janetzki failed to front media for more than a week, and details of the blast slowly leaked out.

Not just a well-loved chocolate

Admittedly, briefing notes from the operator released by the government — an extraordinary step in itself — would be a struggle for anyone without an engineering background to grasp.

Bureaucrats and journalists alike learnt that a clinker was not just a well-known chocolate, but hardened ash that forms at coal-fired power stations and needs to be removed.

But probing further may have helped Mr Janetzki shed further light on the serious incident.

The CS Energy board took the hit for the under-fire minister. (AAP: Darren England)

Mr Janetzki has already taken steps to ensure he won't have to go through this again, implementing real-time updates for any future outages.

A further source of frustration for the government will be that the Callide facility has become its first scandal, after using it as an attack line for so long in opposition.

An explosion at the power plant in 2021 left nearly half a million homes without power.

'Being in government can be hard'

An expert report into the incident only came to light last year, with the then-LNP opposition calling for energy minister at the time Mick de Brenni to be sacked.

"Queenslanders' energy bills went up because of Labor's Callide cover-up. Ministers must be held accountable," a June 2024 media release from Mr Janetzki stated.

A re-energised Mr Miles was in his element in a press conference on Monday. (ABC News: Kenji Sato)

As pointed out almost gleefully by Opposition Leader Steven Miles this week, "being in government can be hard".

The past week may have rammed that home for Mr Janetzki.

Lights are back on at Labor HQ

Mr Miles's campaigning efforts may have prevented an all-out whitewash at the October state election, but Labor was still battered and bruised after being thrown out of government.

Callide operator concedes it 'understated the gravity' of explosion Photo shows A power station surrounded by trees. One of Central Queensland power plant's generators will be offline until the end of May after a blast on April 4.

It's struggled to get much cut through in opposition, often screaming into the abyss about health cuts.

A slew of natural disasters has also made its task difficult, not wanting to be seen making cheap political points in a crisis.

The past week it's managed to occupy the vacuum left by the government's incoherent narrative, all too eager to return serve on the shots it was forced to endure thanks to the beleaguered power station.

A re-energised Mr Miles was in his element in a press conference on Monday, seemingly wrapping up a response to a question about the saga, before what seemed to be an actual light bulb moment.

"And just one other thing on that topic", he said before launching into another attack line.

A long-awaited review into Queensland Health's capacity expansion program released this week is likely to mean the government will need to extend the timeline for its delivery of thousands of new hospital beds, delivering what Labor hope will be another win.

title: At 82, Jeanne is still charting a 'marvellous' solo life on the high seas
text:
A simple mantra has helped Jeanne Socrates endure tough times alone at sea.

"It can't last forever. If I can get through this time, I'll be fine," the 82-year-old said of the positive mindset she lives by.

"That's the thing that keeps me going."

The British yachtswoman, who is sailing up the east coast of Australia, has spent plenty of time navigating the sometimes challenging conditions of the ocean.

She has faced "really rough seas" and endured a major accident when she was thrown off her boat around a decade ago.

"I broke my neck, I 'stove-in' my rib cage, had major internal injuries," she recounted.

"I was in a bad way and I took quite a time to recuperate."

Ms Socrates has been sailing for three decades. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

But the determined Ms Socrates did not let her injuries get in the way of her dreams.

Years after her accident, Ms Socrates became recognised by Guinness World Records as the oldest woman to sail a yacht solo around the world without stopping — a feat she completed in 2019.

That voyage took the then 77-year-old sailor almost a year to complete, and culminated with her travelling through the Five Great Capes of the Southern Ocean.

"You can't pull into land, you've got to be at sea all the time," she said.

"The further I got, the less likely I was to give up.

"I put too much into it to think of giving up."

Jeanne Socrates completed her record sail around the world in 2019. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Ms Socrates said she kept in touch with people via radio each day, as she circumnavigated the globe solo on her vessel, Nereida, which she calls her "partner" and "team mate".

"I could feel almost spiritually, I could feel that a lot of people were with me," she said.

"You don't feel so isolated when you've got the radio."

'Use it or lose it'

Ms Socrates started sailing in her 50s so she could watch seabirds, and became "completely hooked".

"You've got these enormous seas and the birds, and the dolphins at times — it's just a marvellous place to be," she said.

Albatrosses are among Ms Socrates' favourite seabirds. (Supplied: Australian Antarctic Division)

She said she still looked for the beauty of birdlife on the ocean, especially large albatrosses.

"They come really close, gliding by, and they look at you in the eye and you're that close to them," she said.

"You think, oh gosh, how privileged am I to be able to be in this situation."

The octogenarian has attributed her good health to decades of sailing.

"Your body is active, keeping your balance all the time. I think that is a help," she said.

"Mentally, you've got to keep thinking about where you're going.

"I think, use it or lose it basically."

Ms Socrates keeps a meticulous sailing logbook. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

After completing her Guinness World Record sail around the world, Ms Socrates has continued sailing, but now enjoys pulling into port and exploring the land on her travels too.

She is currently taking her time to explore what the east coast of Australia has to offer.

"You meet lovely people, everyone helps each other, it's a lovely community," she said.

"You get the sailing as a bonus."

Ms Socrates says her yacht Nereida is her "teammate" and "partner". (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Later this month, Ms Socrates plans to dock in Port Stephens, in the NSW Hunter region, where she will spend a few months on land writing her autobiography.

After that, with no set destination in mind, she says she will go wherever the sea takes her.

More women in sailing

Shelley Wright, who in 2014 founded the group Women Who Sail Australia, said Ms Socrates was an inspiration to other female sailors.

Shelley Wright started sailing in the 1980s. (Supplied)

Dr Wright said when she set up the group to encourage more women to get into the "male-dominated industry", she had no idea how many female sailors were already taking to the high seas.

"When we got to 300 [members], we thought that it was pretty amazing. I had no idea that there were 300 women out there sailing at that point," she said.

The group now boasts more than 7,000 members.

Dr Wright said Ms Socrates — who is also connected to the online group — was a trailblazer.

"It's mind blowing. The energy and the enthusiasm and the friendship, it's pretty impressive," Dr Wright said.

Ms Socrates heads off on the next leg of her voyage. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Ms Socrates said she was still "pretty determined" to continue sailing into her later years.

"I just want to keep on going for as long as I can. I don't know how long that will be," she said.

"Obviously my body is aging. You can't get away from that.

"But I can't visualise life without being on Nereida."

title: Boarding schools urged to make room for bush students with autism
text:
According to his mum, 12-year-old Dustin Neilsen is "just a normal bush kid" who likes to be outside with his pet dogs, build with Lego and play his electric guitar.

This year he should have started year 7 at boarding school, but his family has had difficulty finding one that will accommodate his needs.

Dustin has autism and despite trying to coordinate a plan with schools and therapists, his parents have been turned down by two schools and told by another to wait 12 months.

"We just want them to give him a chance, and that's probably the thing that concerns us the most is people don't give him a chance," his mother Melissa Neilsen said.

Homeschooling was the only option because the family lives on a cattle farm more than an hour from the closest high school near Hughenden, 400 kilometres inland from Townsville in north-west Queensland.

"We feel like if he stays home, he's not going to get exposed to any of those social things and the older he gets, the more reclusive he may become," Ms Neilsen said.

The Neilsens live on a cattle farm near Hughenden, which leaves Dustin with little choice but to attend a boarding school. (ABC Rural: Brooke Tindall)

Dustin took part in a two-day boarding school experience with a Townsville school last year but the Neilsens were told he could not be accommodated at the dormitory at that time.

"I felt really guilty, like it was all my fault," Dustin said.

The school told the ABC it worked with the Neilsen family for months to assess Dustin's needs and determined he was not ready.

In a statement, the school said the boarding management team and the school's leadership team were not confident Dustin had the capacity to live communally and there were concerns for his safety and that of the other students.

"The school did not deny the child a position in boarding due to autism," the statement read.

"A decision was made to postpone the offer of a position in boarding for 12 months due to the child not being considered adequately successfully ready to enter a communal environment."

Ms Neilsen wants boarding schools to give her son a chance. (ABC Rural: Brooke Tindall)

Ms Neilsen believes the two-day experience did not give Dustin enough time to adjust to the boarding routine.

"He definitely would need time to adjust and adapt, but he has more supports than any other person," she said.

The Hughenden branch of the Isolated Children's Parents' Association (ICPA) is taking Dustin's story to its state conference in June.

ICPA president Wendy Henning said she was aware of many cases where families had opted to do high schooling at home because a boarding school could not accommodate their needs.

"We are very aware of the increasing numbers of neurodivergent children throughout Queensland and the need for education, regardless of where they're getting it, to be able to facilitate various learners," she said.

Autism Awareness Australia chief executive Nicole Rogerson says schools should have the issue of neurodivergence "on their radar". (ABC News: Billy Cooper)

Call for inclusivity

Autism Awareness Australia chief executive Nicole Rogerson said the situation highlighted the need for schools to consider inclusivity in their dormitories.

"Ideally schools would already have this issue on their radar and be planning for it," she said.

Ms Rogerson suggested adjustments to the boarding environment, including sensory-friendly dorm rooms, quiet break spaces, flexible meal options and staff training.

"This isn't about creating special accommodations," she said.

" It's about applying universal design so that all students feel safe and supported. "

Melissa Neilsen says Dustin is "a normal bush kid". (ABC Rural: Brooke Tindall)

The Queensland Department of Education said state schools with boarding facilities could make reasonable adjustments to support the individual needs of neurodivergent students and all students with disabilities.

Independent Schools Queensland was contacted for comment but did not respond by deadline.

Despite the enrolment process taking a toll, Dustin is looking forward to going to boarding school.

He said he was working hard with his support network to prepare for the enrolment process next year.

"I have a lot of [occupational therapists] and people who help me understand who I am as a person," Dustin said.

" But of all the people my mum is the person who's taught me the most in life. "

title: Horse still missing a week after Man From Snowy River re-enactment goes awry
text:
A horse remains missing in Victoria's high country one week on from a live re-enactment of The Man From Snowy River poem that went awry.

The re-enactment of Banjo Patterson's famous poem is an annual treat at the three-day Man From Snowy River Bush Festival, which kicked off on April 11 across three days in the tiny town of Corryong, near the Victorian-NSW border.

However, the 30th edition of the iconic bushman's ballad, a highlight of the opening day's festivities, did not go to plan.

It was anticipated that a group of horses and stockmen would corral 11 unbridled gallopers, including the famous "colt from Old Regret", back to the station to the cheers and hoots of the crowd.

A crowd of more than 5,000 watched as the horses galloped off into the hills.

It was the last time one of the 11 gallopers would be seen for at least a week.

The Man From Snowy River Bush Festival in Corryong, Victoria. ( ) The performers getting ready for the show. (ABC Rural: Annie Brown) The Man From Snowy River Bush Festival in Corryong, Victoria. ( ) The horses take off during the live performance. (ABC Rural: Annie Brown) The Man From Snowy River Bush Festival in Corryong, Victoria. ( ) Guy McLean, dressed as Jim Craig, heads off after the horses. (ABC Rural: Annie Brown) The Man From Snowy River Bush Festival in Corryong, Victoria, April 2025 ( ) The horses run into the hills. (ABC Rural: Annie Brown) The Man From Snowy River Bush Festival in Corryong, Victoria. ( ) Guy McLean leads some horses. (ABC Rural: Annie Brown)

The riders lost the gallopers in the hilly Victorian countryside.

Horse trainer Guy McLean, who was playing Jim Craig, the main character from the 1982 film of the same name, piped up after a few tense minutes.

"I know what you're thinking, you think we lost them don't ya?," he called over the speakers.

Then mid-sentence, the generator stopped. The microphone cut out.

And the real horse mustering began.

The crowd was entertained by the unexpected turn of events. ( )

The show must go on

After the show, Mr McLean's voice was rasping from yelling and his horse was wet with sweat from galloping.

Ten of the 11 horses had been collected in an epic display of horse handling.

Mr McLean, who has more than 30 years of performing experience, said riders had to learn to "roll with the horses".

"The gentlemen that are running those horses are some of the best riders in the country," he said.

"It's hard mountain country here, it's the real deal.

Mr McLean says the show was thrilling, even if it didn't go according to plan. ( )

"There were wombat holes, there were rocks, a lot of the times our horses are on a 45-degree angle."

Mr McLean said although things didn't go exactly to plan, it was one of the most thrilling performances of his careers.

"This was real — there's no fakery to it," he said with a grin.

"I think the riders might be a little hurt it didn't go to plan, but we still put on a show for people."

The riders still put on a show with the "unpredictable" horses. ( )

Three decades celebrating the Man From Snowy River

This year marked the 30th anniversary of the festival, which runs over three days, attracting more than 27,000 people into the town with a population of 1,300.

In terms of economics for the area, it is huge.

People stick around the region for days eating, drinking, and enjoying the festivities.

It's opined that Paterson based the poem's main character on Jack Riley from nearby Corryong, a legendary horseman who was buried in the local cemetery in 1914.

More than 27,000 people attended the festival over three days. ( )

Bush poet Geoffrey Graham has attended and performed at the festival since it began.

He said the festival's success came from the community spirit it generated.

"You've really got to go to a festival like this to feel what the essence of being Australian is," he said.

"You’ll never see or feel this type of history anywhere else."

Mr Graham performed in character as Banjo Paterson and recited poems to the mesmerised crowd.

Bush poet Geoffrey Graham performs in front of the crowd. ( )

Horse still missing

By the end the weekend, all but one of the horses had been found.

The missing beast is presumably still roaming the high country.

Mr Graham reflected on the nature of working with the animals.

"When you're around horses, it's unpredictable, you've got to adapt and be flexible," he said.

"Life is about being flexible — that's an Australian philosophy."

title: North of North is set in the Arctic but will make you feel warm and fuzzy
text:
A few years ago, Inuuk actors Anna Lambe and Maika Harper were doing a screen test in Germany, of all places, when they realised they had a shared dream.

"We were outside a pub chatting about how much we wanted a comedy for Indigenous people that's not trauma-centred, is funny and silly and complex," Lambe tells ABC Entertainment.

"[We thought] maybe eventually it'll come around — and maybe we'll be a part of it."

With North of North, everything they dreamed came true.

It's the first TV series of its size to be set and filmed in Nunavut — the biggest and most northern territory of Canada, which stretches across most of the country's Arctic region.

Loading YouTube content

The new coming-of-age comedy follows Inuk woman Siaja (Lambe) as she sets out to reinvent herself after a lifetime spent putting other people first.

Now 26 years old, she went from taking care of her mother Neevee (Harper) — who struggled with alcoholism in Siaja's childhood — to looking after her man-child husband Ting (Kelly William) alongside raising their six-year-old daughter Bun (Keira Cooper).

But life as a stay-at-home mum isn't for Siaja. So, she dumps Ting and starts looking for a job.

Reinventing herself in the small (fictional) town of Ice Cove is another challenge entirely: in a community where Inuit women are expected to devote their lives to raising children, Siaja's decision to work for the problematic and clueless white woman running the town community centre isn't popular.

Siaja's (left) new boss Helen (right) has good intentions, but couldn't be more exasperating. (Netflix)

An 'unapologetically Inuk' series

Told in a mix of English and Inuktitut, North of North fuses a breadth of Inuit comedic styles — from the dry and witty to the broad and physical — creating characters that feel real and a world that's impossible to resist.

At the same time, the series doesn't shy away from the deeper issues that impact First Nations people: colonialism and its ongoing myriad impacts; tension between individualism and community; and intergenerational trauma and healing.

The contrast between light and dark makes both elements hit harder.

North of North's creators say the costumes on the show are representative of the fashion any visitor to the Arctic could expect to see. (Netflix)

Each of the series' eight episodes showcase different aspects of Inuit cultural identity, all while featuring vibrant costume design that draws inspiration from styles across the Arctic.

North of North also boasts a soundtrack including the likes of Caroline Polachek, Remi Wolf, Doja Cat and Alanis Morrisette, as well as Inuk covers of Dua Lipa's Levitating, from Riit, and Fleetwood Mac's Dreams, by Elisapie.

The result is a nuanced show that's surprising and heartbreaking at times, but also heartwarming, joyful and easy to watch.

Lambe describes it as "so unapologetically Inuk".

North of North could only have been made by Inuit filmmakers

Stacey Aglok MacDonald and Alethea Arnaquq-Baril have been producing TV and movies in the Arctic for 20 years, and had the same dream of seeing their community represented.

They also knew from the outset that they wanted to use North of North as a way to help develop the television industry in Iqaluit, the Nunavut city where the show was shot.

So, they launched a mentorship program, which saw local trainees work in roles across departments throughout production, and hosted drama workshops for local actors, from which they cast some roles in the show — including Iqaluit's mayor, Solomon Awa.

North of North was set in the fake Nunavut town of Ice Cove, which is really Iqaluit. (Netflix)

The main cast is predominantly First Nations, with actors from other parts of Canada, Alaska and even New Zealand, and there were a number of Indigenous crew members.

Many Iqaluit residents also appear as extras throughout the series — the community feels as much like its own character in the show as the stunning Arctic landscapes.

"[The Iqaluit locals in the show] have all been getting so much love and shout-outs from within our community," Aglok MacDonald says.

"We even had a shot of a loose dog walking across the street and someone posted it on socials and they were like, 'Someone's dog made it to North of North!'"

'Comedy is a protective measure': Hacks stars talk making TV under Trump Photo shows Ava and Deborah, dressed up, press their faces together in a photoshoot in Hacks. Hacks stars Jean Smart and Hannah Einbinder talk comedy's power to platform women in Hollywood beyond their looks.

Lambe feels shooting in Iqaluit under the care of two Inuuk showrunners ensured that cultural safety and the production's impact on the community stayed front of mind.

"I think, in terms of Indigenous film and television, Indigenous representation [and] how to engage with [these] communities, it sets a new precedent," she says.

Aotearoa/New Zealand actor Jay Ryan, who plays an outsider in North of North visiting Ice Cove for research, agrees.

He recently starred in the Northern Territory-based Netflix show The Territory, which enjoyed a similar level of buzz for its representation of Indigenous people in Australia after its 2024 release — but thinks North of North reaches another level.

"Territory was great … it felt like a co-production with a lens on creating pathways for Indigenous crew members and cast, and that was a great stepping stone," he says.

"But North of North … was fully led by Indigenous creatives, cast, crew. I was the minority for once."

Jay Ryan (left) with Maika Harper (right), was on location in Nunavut for almost five months and says the few outsiders on the show were brought into the Iqaluit community "as family". (Netflix)

Filming a TV show with a 100-strong crew in the Arctic

By all accounts, it would have been easier to film the majority of North of North somewhere like Toronto, and spend only a few weeks shooting in Iqaluit.

The show was the largest-scale project Aglok MacDonald or Arnaquq-Baril had attempted — and that Nunavut had ever seen.

The sets were built in Ontario, dismantled and then had to be either flown or shipped to Iqaluit, which cannot be reached by road from mainland Canada.

Some of the logistics had to be planned a year in advance, considering things such as when the ocean would freeze over.

Filming in -30°C weather was a standard day for the cast and crew on North of North. (Netflix)

Finding accommodation for a crew of 100 in a town of 8,000 also proved difficult: there are only so many hotels in Iqaluit, and when a big symposium was on at the same time as filming, the cast and crew had to leave Nunavut for a week.

And there was, of course, the frigid weather. Temperatures in Iqaluit are below freezing for an average of eight months a year.

In the show's first episode, two characters kiss outside. Ryan remembers it being -30°C at the time, and says the actors had to do the shot over 17 times.

But Ryan thinks the extreme cold fostered a sense of community among the cast and crew, saying there was a "real kind of school-camp mentality" at the hotel they stayed at — particularly on blizzard days, when they were forced inside.

And filming entirely on location makes North of North a Nunavut project through and through, so they wouldn't have it another way.

The Iqaluit community feels as much like its own character in North of North as the breathtaking Arctic landscapes depicted in the show. (Netflix)

There's no word yet on a second season but, with the first finally out in the world, Arnaquq-Baril has one wish.

"I hope [viewers] want to come north and are intrigued by our part of the world," she says.

"I think a lot of people don't know we exist or, if they do know anything about Inuit, they tend to think of us as historical figures — a culture that once was.

" [I hope they] see that we are still here, always have been, and that we're funny and interesting and that they might admire our sense of community, that we stick together — through thick and thin and through insanity and trauma and laughs and joy. "

North of North is streaming now on Netflix.
